meanings.definition: To make something common or shared among a group of people.
meanings.sent1: The teacher decided to communise the snacks by sharing them equally among the students.
meanings.sent2: In the community garden, they communise the tools so everyone can use them.
meanings.sent3: At the picnic, they communised the drinks to ensure everyone had enough to drink.
meanings.sent4: The idea of communising the toys in the daycare made playtime more enjoyable for all the children.
meanings.sent5: The decision to communise the chores among the roommates helped create a harmonious living environment.

meanings.definition: To establish a system of communal ownership and control.
meanings.sent1: The group of friends wanted to communise their savings to invest in a project together.
meanings.sent2: The community decided to communise the land for farming to benefit all residents.
meanings.sent3: The plan to communise the library books sparked a lively discussion among the members.
meanings.sent4: The company's decision to communise decision-making led to increased collaboration among employees.
meanings.sent5: The village chose to communise the resources to ensure fair distribution among all families.
